awd_titl_txt: Probing the Quark Gluon Plasma with Jet Tomography
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the fundamental theory of the strong nuclear force, predicts the existence of a novel state of matter with liberated quarks and gluons known as the Quark-Gluon Plasma (QGP). During ultra-relativistic heavy ion collisions, nuclei melt into fundamental constituents, forming a QGP. At the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC), this unique form of matter was discovered to behave like a nearly perfect liquid. Nuclear physicists continue to explore new regions of this phase transition and to reveal its detailed signatures, with RHIC providing the widest range of collision energies and systems and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) reaching the highest temperatures and energy densities. This award will support the PI's research on quantitatively characterizing properties of this hot QCD matter through a study of energetic quarks and gluons in collisions at LHC and RHIC.  The PI will combine active research with outreach and education to increase minority participation in STEM careers, including nuclear physics.

The PI will measure discriminative jet observables in relativistic heavy ion collisions along with their reference collisions. To map out the phase diagram at varying length scales, the PI and her group will measure center of mass energy dependence of jet shapes and heavy flavor quark jets at lower kinematic regions where the mass effects are expected to be non-negligible. By finalizing the small radii dependence of inclusive jets at large kinematic range, the PI will improve the pp baseline for 5 TeV collisions to distinguish between competing physics mechanisms of parton energy loss. These complementary and robust measurements will determine key features of the QGP including thermodynamical and transport coefficient of plasma, how the hot QCD medium responds to jet energy loss, and how it affects jet structures.   The PI will foster a diverse and competitive work force by emphasizing the education of female and underrepresented minority students in STEM majors in general, and nuclear physics in particular, via integration of education with active research. To reduce the loss of potential students of all ages, she will encourage female middle and high school students to pursue university education in STEM fields by bringing them to Rutgers, recruit undergraduate physics majors by incorporating forefront high energy nuclear physics research into her introductory physics courses, and mentor women and underrepresented minority students and include them in all phases of research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has laid important groundwork for future research in both theoretical and experimental nuclear physics, utilizing the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) accelerator facilities. The Rutgers University (RU) group's research focused on precision measurements of jet variables and jet cross-sections, as well as their comparison with theoretical calculations of perturbative quantum chromodynamics (QCD). These findings are crucial for the ongoing development of Monte Carlo simulations, which are essential tools for modeling nuclear collisions. The results of this project will help improve these simulations, leading to more accurate predictions of jet behavior in environments such as the LHC at CERN and in heavy-ion collisions at RHIC at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

Key outcomes of this project include the study of jet momentum, mass, shape, and angular correlations within jets. Comparisons of jet momentum distributions reconstructed from proton-proton collisions at LHC energies, with perturbative QCD predictions, indicate that next-to-next-to-leading order calculations more accurately reproduce the measured cross-sections than next-to-leading order calculations, with significantly less dependence on factorization scale choices. To provide further crucial input for tuning Monte Carlo simulations, the underlying events associated with a high transverse momentum jet and the first inclusive measurements of the invariant and groomed jet mass—defined as the magnitude of the four-momentum sum of the jet constituents in pp collisions at RHIC energies—were also studied. The kinematic range of jet shapes at lower transverse momenta is broadened by conducting the first measurement of inclusive jet shape analysis at RHIC energies. Additionally, the RU group explored angular correlations among jet constituents by constraining a trigger jet in azimuth relative to the event plane. A more systematic understanding of jet shapes, focusing on generalized angularities, is performed. These studies not only provide crucial insights into the angular correlations within jet constituents but also offer a comprehensive examination of splitting measurements, shedding light on the evolution of various contributions, including next-to-leading order effects and hadronization. Following the initial studies of heavy flavor-tagged jet measurements conducted by the principal investigator's group, which demonstrated no strong dependence on parton flavor, the exploration of mass dependence continued with a study of the radial profile of D0 meson distance from the jet axis. At RHIC energies, no apparent diffusion is observed. Despite this finding, changes in fragmentation functions and momentum spectra were observed in jets with a D0 meson. Additionally, azimuthal and triangular flow analyses of D0 mesons from B decays revealed a non-zero triangular flow component. The centrality-dependent comparison of Z boson measurements in Pb-Pb collisions enabled a pioneering data-driven determination of centrality.

This project also had a significant impact on training and mentorship. Graduate and undergraduate students, as well as a postdoctoral fellow involved in this research, are now well-prepared to lead future research efforts in nuclear physics. Their experience in both experimental techniques and data analysis will contribute to shaping the future of the field.

In summary, this project has advanced the understanding of QCD, heavy quark behavior, and nuclear collisions while also fostering technological developments in detector design and supporting the next generation of nuclear physicists. These outcomes set the stage for future discoveries in nuclear physics and will continue to drive innovation in the field.
